page.lettertext:
fol.108r
Belgia 1591 stil Ro
m
20 March to my L Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: March:
May it please yo
r
good L. yo
r
letters of the 13 22 and
25 of Februarie were delivered unto mee the 4 & 5
th
of
this moneth, and now by
S
r
John Norreis
who arrived at
the Hage
e 7
th
daie at night, I receaved one from her
Ma
ty
of the 1 and an oth
r
from yo
r
L. of the second of this p
nt
and also a third of the 23 of Feb
r
w
ch
I have receaved
in good sort w
th
all
e writing
thereinclosed of w
ch
yo
r
letters make mention. and first I am delivered of a
combersome care, to see her Ma
t
good liking to concurre
w
th
my
ceeding in
e staie of the Comp
ies
. for although I
were assured having thorowlie consydered the condition of this
state, and
e bent of
e people,
t
I had taken at that
exigent an apparant good course, for
e advancem
t
of her
service, yet I feared now, & then, least her Hig
nes
might
be willing for some secret intention to have
e comp
ies
disbanded.
But now
t
I am comforted w
th
her gratious approbation
as well of this, as in generall of all my services in this
place, I am to entreat yo
r
L. w
th
all humble earnestnes
to c
o
tinew yo
r
wonted favor in gracing my
ceeding
, and
to signify for mee to her Ma
ty
, that although my devotion
bee alredy in that degree, that it cannot be augmented
yet if either industry and care, or oth
r
endevo
r
whatsoever
may
make it more eminent, there shalbee nothing heer omitted,
that may redound in any sort to her princely content.
And for aunswere to such pointes, as her Hig
nes
hath
vouchesafed to c
o
mit unto my charge, I have laboured very
earnestly to finde
e reason of those advertisement
, of the
meeting toward
in
e towne of
Utrecht,
and of
e entercowrse
of trafficq w
t
Dunkerk
&
Newport.
But if it bee possible
for mee, by being heer in place, and ob
s
ving their actions
and judging somewhat of my self by common cowrse of
discretion, to conject arighte of those occurences, it is either
a practise of
e Ennemy to occasion a breach between her
Hig
nes
and
e
States,
or els a meer imagination of some
weak intelligence. For I see not so much as the smallest
apparance, to suppose it to be trew. first for Utrecht
fol.108v
Belgia: 1591: Ma
r
though I hold it assured, that 3
tes of the inhabitant
[.]
are more ill affected in
e cause of religion, or not at all
affected to any manner of religion: & besides a headstro
ng
people & mutinous, & naturallie subject to desire innovation
yet when all is well weighed I see no cause to imagine
that they will fall from
e union. Again it is not possible
as
e forme of this government is composed, that either
those
t
are named of
e Ennemies country, or any that
are heer of
e assembly of
e States, should resort to
such a place but it must bee notified all abroad. And as
for
t
w
ch
is reported of
e accord upon traffique, it carieth
no conformity w
th
those courses, that are held by Holland &
Zeland
: nor there is no meanes in this state, to contrive a
matter of that moment, w
th
out
e privity of many, & the
notice of this Councell. And at this very p
nt
the
States of Zeland ar suto
rs
heer, that
e sauvegarde of
Flandres
may be wholie revoked, no contribution receaved of
the Boores, but every part of
e Countrey, that hath bin
lately possessed, to be reputed as Ennemy. For w
ch
they
present that since that Province was brought in contribution
multitudes of Fleming
w
ch
were wont to dwell in Zeland
are retourned into Flandres, wh
r
by their state is decaied
both in nomb
rs
of Inhabitant
& in wealth, & not so able as
before, to beare
e burden of their charge. but
e
Councel
unwilling to favo
r
their motion, because they do acchount it
[an] uncharitable act, & it would bee p
r
judiciall to their good in
other places. In effect I am
suaded that neither of those
report
hath any manner of good ground. Howbeit if [it]
should so fall out, as her Hig
nes
is informed, I will not
fail to be as vigilant, as is possible for mee, both in
venting their dessires, & in making
e remonstrance
t
her
Ma
ty
hath p
r
scrbed. And likewise for
e project th[at yo
r
]
L. hath sent, when any occasion shalbee for it, it [shall be]
proposed as I am charged by her Hig
nes
& yo
r
L. [.]
downe. But wee have heard no more of late of the[.]
commissioners: w
ch
putteth manye men in dout, that the [.]
yet in
Brabant.
And as it seemeth by some letters [.]
fol.109r
Belgia: 1591: March:
have lately intercepted, by secret adv
r
tisement
from the
Ennemies Contrey, & by sondry good tokens, they are
wholy out of hope of inducing this people to a
treaty of peace. It is thought in that behalf that
their l
re
to
e
Empero
r
hath don a great deale of
good, And for my self I am resolved, that both
their state was nev
r
better, in respect of their wealth
to c
o
tinew their warre, nor
e people lesse enclined
to accord w
th
e ennemy. My onely dout was of
late, w
ch
was also the feare of the best of these
countreys, that S
r
John Norreis c
o
ing heth
r
for so
many Companies, and
e people heer imagining, that
it tended to no other, but to w
th
draw her Hig
nes
succo
rs
for altogether, they might chaunce upon
e soddain
the motion of peace being then sett on foote, to take some
sinister cowrse to
e ruin of their state. Howbeit this
occasion of feare is wholy now surceased, &
e people
highly pleased, that her Ma
t
demand is framed to
theyr mindes, as I think they will acknowledge in return
of theyr answere, w
ch
we expect every houre. And as
for those
t
are deputed to negotiate this peace, they
will not hazard to come hether w
th
out a passport from
e
States, w
ch
I am very well assured they shall never obtain.
And if up
o
refusall they shall offer to publish theyr
message in writing, I will follow yo
r
L. order proposed
in
e project, and as much as may be requisit, aswell
for ob
s
ving
e meetest occasions, as for ev
r
y oth
r
circumstance
I hope shall accomplish to such effect as yo
u
desire. An
opportunity
s
ving for this bearer to de
te & her Ma
ty
expecting an expedite answear, I thought it best to
dispatch him, w
th
as much as doth
tain to her principall
affaires: and for
e rest of those point
wherin my
service is required, my next after this shall advertise
at full. I have heerw
th
sent a l
re
written to
her Ma
ty
from
e
D. of Florence
, w
ch
was delivered heer
unto mee, by
e post of
e m
r
chant
of these countryes
fol.108v
Belgia: 1591: March.
To my L. Treasurer March 10 1590
that goeth wekely for
Germany.
Hee was lately taken in
his waie and rifled by c
r
tain frebuting souldiers, either of
Berghen,
or of
Diest:
who as hee complaineth in serching
for mony and l
re
s of exchange, opened divers of his
pacquet
& l
re
s, and amongest
e rest this l
re
to her
Ma
ty
, w
ch
becaus hee knew not among many, w
th
w
ch
of his pacquet
it was consigned, hee brought it heer
to mee so unsealed as I send it, togeth
r
w
th
e copie
w
ch
was also displaced and found w
th
oth
r
writing
. As
farr as I c
a
conjecture
e letter was addressed to some
Italian of
London,
as happely yo
r
L. will know by
enquirie.
And so I take &c. March 10 1590./
